children.subject: To be suitably prepared for 189 you should ideally take 127, 126/140, and maybe math 110 if possible (not as important imo)
What are the pros and cons of taking 126 vs 140? I took CS 70 but heard that the later parts of 126 not related to probability are not particularly useful

Latter half of 126 is not pure probability and not related to 189 afaik, but that's not to say it's not useful. In general I suggest that if you have a strong grasp of the probability in 70, you should take 126 and if not, 140. Both classes are sufficient in terms of probability prep for 189

As Professor Sahai said, if you are EECS, you take EECS 126, if you are Data Science, you take Stats 140. EECS 126 has incredible amount of hws (like at least 12-15 hours of work each week for average students in the class) and a lab each week (not particularly long, but may also take substantial conceptual understanding) It is not very related to 189, and won't affect your standing in 189, but definitely can help a bit for 189. In general it's a very hybrid and insanely hard class, ranging from Probability, Information Theory, Markov Chains, one lecture of random graph, and decisions. 

You will not be surprised to see a lot of your 70 TAs taking the class with you (if you just finish 70) and they may not even be the most brilliant ones in the class. People say top 10% of CS 70 students are average ones in this class, because the class is a relatively smaller size and students who will take 189 may take stats 134 or 140 as an alternative so you can see the distribution that all geniuses just clutter into this infamous class

I would disagree with this. Although it's possible some 126 homeworks take longer than average for EECS classes, it's not the staff's intent to make it prohibitively hard, or to purely reward being a "genius" - and there's also plenty of OH offered. Some material may be difficult to understand on the first attempt, but I don't think that's specific to 126. The class does cover a lot of topics, but none really at a level substantially more difficult than other classes like 189.

Oh I guess I'm stylizing 126 in a negative way by saying "infamous", all I wanna say is it's just a really hard class, so students who want to take it as a prerequisite should not think so. Also by brilliant I guess I want to say the term "accomplished", it is still like every class at Berkeley, as long as you contribute to it a lot, you will gain your reward. Im not trying to say that the course is designed to reward geniuses, its just that more accomplished EECS students come to this class, and as its curved, it makes the competition rly hard. In general I feel like I learned incredibly a lot, but my grades were not the optimal
What other classes are necessary besides cs 70?

history.content:
Pre-reqs in the CS dept aren't enforced so it is possible; however, I would recommend waiting to take the recommended classes first unless you feel you had a solid understanding of their applications in 189


+edit

189 has lots of optimizations which are covered in 127, and those optimizations covered in 127 requires linear algebra techniques from 16B. Take your time to build up the knowledge. It wouldn't work out.

Pre-reqs in the CS dept aren't enforced so it is possible; however, I would recommend waiting to take the recommended classes first unless you feel you had a solid understanding of their applications in 189

children.subject:
The system will allow you to enroll without those pre-reqs but that doesn't mean you will be successful. Also keep in mind that the professors have until the end of week 2 to drop any students how hasn't met the pre-reqs. It is at their discretion to do so.

Cindy Conners
CS Enrollment Manager

history.content: It says math 53 and math 54 are pre requisites for cs 189. But is it possible to do it with just EE16A and EE16B? How about without 16B?
history.subject: Cs 189
